messages.content: What's the difference between  "I am coming home" and "I came home."

The sentence "I am coming home" is in the progressive form, it is used to express an action that is in progress or happening now.

Whereas the sentence "I came home" is in the simple past form, it is used to express an action that has been completed in the past.

So, the main difference between the two sentences is the time frame in which the action is taking place. "I am coming home" is in the present progressive, while "I came home" is in the past simple.
Then, how about "I will come home."

The sentence "I will come home" is in the future simple form, it is used to express an action that will take place in the future.

It is different from "I am coming home" which is in the progressive form and it is used to express that the action is happening now.
And "I came home" which is in the past simple form and it is used to express that the action was completed in the past.

So, the main difference between "I will come home" and "I am coming home" is the time frame in which the action is taking place. "I will come home" is in the future simple, while "I am coming home" is in the present progressive.
Then, how about "I would come home."

The sentence "I would come home" is in the past subjunctive form, it is used to express a hypothetical or uncertain situation. It is different from the other forms because it uses the past subjunctive form of the verb "come".
It is used to express an action that may or may not have happened in the past, depending on the circumstances or conditions.
It is different from "I am coming home" and "I came home" which are in the simple present or simple past form, and express actions that are certain or have already happened.

So, the main difference between "I would come home" and "I am coming home" or "I came home" is the time frame in which the action is taking place and the way it is expressed. "I would come home" is in the past subjunctive, while "I am coming home" and "I came home" are in the simple past or simple present form.
